children.title: Executives fail to support project
children.description: The project team may lack the authority to achieve project objectives. In such cases, executive management support is fundamental to project success. When this doesn't materialize the project fails.

children.title: Executives become disengaged with project
children.description: Executive management disregards project communications and meetings.

children.title: Conflict between executive stakeholders disrupts project
children.description: Members of executive management are combative to the project or there is a disagreement over project issues at the executive level.

children.title: Executive turnover disrupts project
children.description: A key executive leaves the company, the resulting disruption becomes a project issue.

children.title: Scope is ill defined
children.description: The general risk of an error or omission in scope definition.

children.title: Scope creep inflates scope
children.description: Uncontrolled changes and continuous growth of scope.

children.title: Gold plating inflates scope
children.description: The project team add their own product features that aren't in requirements or change requests.

children.title: Estimates are inaccurate
children.description: Inaccurate estimates is a common project risk.

children.title: Dependencies are inaccurate
children.description: Dependencies dramatically impact the project schedule and costs.

children.title: Activities are missing from scope
children.description: Required activities are missing from scope definition.

children.title: Cost forecasts are inaccurate
children.description: Inaccurate cost estimates and forecasts.

children.title: Exchange rate variability
children.description: When costs are incurred in foreign currencies exchange rates can have a dramatic impact.

children.title: Change management overload
children.description: A large number of change requests dramatically raises the complexity of the project and distracts key resources.

children.title: Stakeholder conflict over proposed changes
children.description: Change requests may be the source of stakeholder conflict.

children.title: Perceptions that a project failed because of changes
children.description: Large numbers of high priority change requests may lead to the perception that the project has failed. When the schedule and budget are continually extended â€” stakeholders may feel the project missed its original targets.

children.title: Lack of a change management system
children.description: Identify any lack of critical tools as a risk.

children.title: Lack of a change management process
children.description: Change management at the organizational or departmental level is critical to project success. Otherwise, the project will have limited visibility into changes that impact the project.

children.title: Lack of a change control board
children.description: A change control board is essential to managing change for large projects.

children.title: Inaccurate change priorities
children.description: When non-essential changes are prioritized impacting critical schedules.

children.title: Low quality of change requests
children.description: Change requests that are low quality (e.g. ambiguous).

children.title: Change request conflicts with requirements
children.description: Change requests that make no sense in the context of the requirements.

children.title: Stakeholders become disengaged
children.description: When stakeholders ignore project communications.

children.title: Stakeholders have inaccurate expectations
children.description: Stakeholders develop inaccurate expectations (believe that the project will achieve something not in the requirements, plan, etc).

children.title: Stakeholder turnover
children.description: Stakeholder turnover can lead to project disruptions.

children.title: Stakeholders fail to support project
children.description: When stakeholders have a negative attitude towards the project and wish to see it fail.

children.title: Stakeholder conflict
children.description: Disagreement between stakeholders over project issues.

children.title: Process inputs are low quality
children.description: Inputs from stakeholders that are low quality (e.g. business case, requirements, change requests).

children.title: Project team misunderstand requirements
children.description: When requirements are misinterpreted by the project team a gap develops between expectations, requirements and work packages.

children.title: Communication overhead
children.description: When key project resources spend a high percentage of their time engaging stakeholders on project issues and change requests their work may fall behind.

children.title: Under communication
children.description: Communication is a challenge that's not to be underestimated. You may need to communicate the same idea many times in different ways before people remember it.

children.title: Users have inaccurate expectations
children.description: The risk that users believe the project is building an apple when you're really building an orange (i.e. users don't understand the product that's coming their way).

children.title: Impacted individuals aren't kept informed
children.description: A stakeholder is missing in your communication plan. Anyone who isn't informed but is impacted has an excellent reason to throw up project roadblocks. For example, if you build a system but fail to consult the operations group that will be responsible for support.

children.title: Resource shortfalls
children.description: Inability to secure sufficient resources for the project.

children.title: Learning curves lead to delays and cost overrun
children.description: When your project team need to acquire new skills for the project there's a risk that productivity will be low.

children.title: Training isn't available
children.description: Quality training for certain skills can be difficult to secure.

children.title: Training is inadequate
children.description: Training is often a poor substitute for professional experience. Projects shouldn't assume that resources will be fully productive in a new skill.

children.title: Resources are inexperienced
children.description: Resources who are just out of school or who are new to your industry or profession tend to make more mistakes and be less productive.

children.title: Resource performance issues
children.description: Resources who perform below expectations.

children.title: Team members with negative attitudes towards the project
children.description: Resources who are negative towards the project may actively or passively sabotage project efforts.

children.title: Resource turnover
children.description: Resource turnover leads to delays and cost overrun.

children.title: Low team motivation
children.description: Your team lacks motivation. This is a particularly common risk for long running projects.

children.title: Lack of commitment from functional managers
children.description: In a matrix organization your team may report to functional managers. These functional managers are important stakeholders whose support is critical.

children.title: Architecture fails to pass governance processes
children.description: Plan for any architectural or technology governance processes that the project may need to pass.

children.title: Architecture lacks flexibility
children.description: The architecture is incapable of supporting change requests and needs to be reworked.

children.title: Architecture is not fit for purpose
children.description: The architecture is low quality.

children.title: Architecture is infeasible
children.description: The architecture is impossible to implement, excessively costly or doesn't support the requirements.

children.title: Design is infeasible
children.description: The design isn't possible, is excessively costly or doesn't support the requirements.

children.title: Design lacks flexibility
children.description: A poor design makes change requests difficult and costly.

children.title: Design is not fit for purpose
children.description: The design is low quality.

children.title: Design fails peer review
children.description: It's a good idea to have peers or architectural experts review your designs.

children.title: Technology components aren't fit for purpose
children.description: Technology components are low quality.

children.title: Technology components aren't scalable
children.description: Components that can't be scaled to meet performance demands.

children.title: Technology components aren't interoperable
children.description: Components that lack standard interfaces.

children.title: Technology components aren't compliant with standards and best practices
children.description: Non-standard components that violate best practices.

children.title: Technology components have security vulnerabilities
children.description: Security vulnerabilities are key technology risks.

children.title: Technology components are over-engineered
children.description: A component that's bloated with unneeded functionality and design features.

children.title: Technology components lack stability
children.description: Components that crash.

children.title: Technology components aren't extensible
children.description: Components that are difficult to extend with new capabilities.

children.title: Technology components aren't reliable
children.description: Components that fail after a short time.

children.title: Information security incidents
children.description: The risk of a a security incident during the project (e.g. information is leaked).

children.title: System outages
children.description: Critical systems such as your test environments go down.

children.title: Legacy components lack documentation
children.description: Integration with undocumented legacy components is a high risk activity.

children.title: Legacy components are out of support
children.description: Integration with legacy components that are no longer in support.

children.title: Components or products aren't maintainable
children.description: Technology components, tools or platforms that are difficult to maintain (e.g. lacking documentation, rare skills, complex or experimental).

children.title: Components or products can't be operationalized
children.description: Technology operations may have criteria for operationalization of new systems that need to be met.

children.title: Project management tool problems & issues
children.description: Technical problems with the project management tools themselves.

children.title: Delays to required infrastructure
children.description: Delays to infrastructure such as hardware or software.

children.title: Failure to integrate with business processes
children.description: The risk that your product will fail to fit into the existing business.

children.title: Failure to integrate with systems
children.description: The risk that your product will fail to integrate with existing systems.

children.title: Integration testing environments aren't available
children.description: The risk that environments won't be available to test integration.

children.title: Failure to integration with the organization
children.description: The risk that your project fails to integrate with the organization. This happens when the project is focused on delivering something specific and fails to look at the organization as a whole. For example, you deliver a sales system but your organization doesn't have a sales team.

children.title: Failure to integrate components
children.description: The risk that product components will fail to integrate with each other. This can represent a significant risk when you've outsourced work to a large number of vendors.

children.title: Project disrupts operations
children.description: The last thing you want is for your project to disrupt business operations and damage the firm's financial results. Think about risks beyond project failure.

children.title: Project disrupts sales
children.description: The risk that the project disrupts sales effectiveness.

children.title: Project disrupts compliance
children.description: The risk that the project disrupts compliance processes such as audits and reporting.

children.title: Requirements fail to align with strategy
children.description: Your requirements conflict with the firm's strategy. If you sense that this is the case, list it as a risk.

children.title: Requirements fail to align with business processes
children.description: The requirements make no sense in the context of the business.

children.title: Requirements fail to align with systems
children.description: The requirements fail to align with other systems (e.g. they duplicate functionality).

children.title: Requirements have compliance issues
children.description: If you have any doubt that requirements comply with the law list it as a risk.

children.title: Requirements are ambiguous
children.description: Requirements are unclear and open to interpretation.

children.title: Requirements are low quality
children.description: Requirements aren't fit for purpose.

children.title: Requirements are incomplete
children.description: You can spot obvious holes in the requirements.

children.title: Decision delays impact project
children.description: Establish guidelines for decision turnaround time. Identify the risk that guidelines will be exceeded.

children.title: Decisions are ambiguous
children.description: Stakeholders may have a tendency to make decisions that are intentionally ambiguous (a responsibility avoidance technique). This can be identified as a risk and managed.

children.title: Decisions are low quality
children.description: Decisions aren't fit for purpose.

children.title: Decisions are incomplete
children.description: Issue resolutions that don't address the issue or create more issues.

children.title: No response to RFP
children.description: The risk that there is limited response to an RFP. This occurs when the RFP terms are unacceptable to vendors or if your firm has a bad reputation amongst vendors.

children.title: Low quality responses to RFP
children.description: Half hearted responses to your RFP that are unusable.

children.title: Failure to negotiation a reasonable price for contracts
children.description: Inability to negotiate a reasonable price for contracts. This occurs when the requirements or contract terms make vendors nervous.

children.title: Unacceptable contract terms
children.description: Inability to negotiate acceptable contract terms.

children.title: Conflict with vendor leads to project issues
children.description: The relationship with vendor turns to conflict and project issues mount.

children.title: Conflict between vendors leads to project issues
children.description: Your vendors develop conflict with each other and cooperation breaks down.

children.title: Vendors start late
children.description: The risk of a late start.

children.title: Vendor components fail to meet requirements
children.description: A vendor misunderstands requirements or delivers components that are completely off the mark.

children.title: Vendor components are low quality
children.description: Vendor components aren't fit for purpose.

children.title: Infrastructure is low quality
children.description: Your infrastructure fails or is not fit for purpose.

children.title: Service quality is low
children.description: Services you procure such as consulting are not fit for purpose.

children.title: Vendor components introduce third party liability
children.description: Vendor components introduce liability (e.g. they violate patents).

children.title: Loss of intellectual property
children.description: Vendors spy on you.

children.title: Project team lack authority to complete work
children.description: If you lack specific authorities required to deliver the project list this as a risk.

children.title: Authority is unclear
children.description: It's unclear who has the authority to accomplish a project objective.

children.title: Delays to stakeholder approvals impact the project
children.description: The risk that approval deadlines will be exceeded.

children.title: Delays to financial approvals impact the project
children.description: The risk of delays to financial approvals and processes to release funds.

children.title: Delays to procurement processes impact the project
children.description: Many organizations have specific procurement processes that must be followed. These processes can be time consuming and highly variable. Document the risk that procurement process will exceed deadlines.

children.title: Delays to recruiting processes impact the project
children.description: If your project involves recruiting resources, this will typically take many months and is highly variable.

children.title: Delays to training impact the project
children.description: If your training budget requires separate approvals (e.g. from functional managers or HR) document the risk that this will be slow.

children.title: The project fails to match the organization's culture
children.description: A culture fit issue between your product and the organization. If the organization's culture calls for employees to bring their own mobile devices to work (BYOD) and you build a user interface that only works on a specific device.

children.title: An organizational restructuring throws the project into chaos
children.description: If your project has a large footprint it may be extremely sensitive to organizational changes.

children.title: A merger or acquisition disrupts the project
children.description: Mergers & acquisitions may represent significant organizational changes.

children.title: Legal & regulatory change impacts project
children.description: If your project spans areas that are compliance-sensitive you may want to list regulatory change as a risk.

children.title: Force Majeure (e.g. act of nature) impacts project
children.description: Major disruptions such as acts of nature.

children.title: Market forces impact project
children.description: Market changes impact project (e.g. a market crash).

children.title: Technical change impacts project
children.description: A technology innovation changes your industry and impacts the project.

children.title: Business change impacts project
children.description: A business innovation changes your industry and impacts the project.

children.title: Failure to follow methodology
children.description: If your organization asks you to streamline your project management methodology, that can be documented as a risk.

children.title: Lack of management or control
children.description: A lack of project management should be documented as a risk. For example, if resource constraints cause the project to skip certain project management best practices.

children.title: Errors in key project management processes
children.description: Errors in project management such as schedule errors.

children.title: Counterparty risk
children.description: The risk you get back when you transfer a risk.

children.title: Users reject the prototype
children.description: One of the key methods of improving user acceptance is to get regular prototypes in front of users. There's always a risk that these prototypes will be rejected (require significant rework).

children.title: User interface doesn't allow users to complete tasks
children.description: The risk that the user interface doesn't allow users to complete end-to-end tasks.

children.title: User interface is low quality
children.description: The user interface is buggy, slow or difficult to use.

children.title: User interface isn't accessible
children.description: In many jurisdictions, user interfaces must be accessible (e.g. employment or consumer law). Many organizational cultures require accessible user interfaces.

children.title: Project reduces business productivity
children.description: Users identify your product(s) as reducing their productivity.

children.title: Project reduces innovation
children.description: Users identify your product(s) as a roadblock to innovation.

children.title: Product disrupts business metrics (measurements of objectives)
children.description: Your product launch causes business KPIs to worsen. For example, if you launch a new ERP and Supply Chain Cycle Times jump.

children.title: Users reject the product
children.description: The general risk that users will reject your product.

children.title: Product doesn't sell
children.description: Demand risk for the new product.

children.title: Product incurs legal liability
children.description: The product has quality issues that harm your customers.

children.title: Product negatively affects brand
children.description: The product has quality issues that damage your brand.

children.title: Product negatively affects reputation
children.description: The product generates negative publicity and/or damages customer relationships.
